clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world called Shibuya Crossing.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming called Akihabara.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 36 million people live in Tokyo's metropolitan area, making it the most populous urban area in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo's subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s that stands on Liberty Island.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters and Times Square.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
New York City has 722 miles of subway track, enough to stretch from NYC to Chicago.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118 and was built in just 410 days.

clues: This city is built on seven hills and has a tiny country within its borders.
Ancient gladiators once fought in a massive stone amphitheater here called the Colosseum.
fun_fact: People throw about €1.5 million into the Trevi Fountain each year, which is collected and donated to charity.
Rome has more than 2,000 fountains, more than any other city in the world.
trivia: The Pantheon in this city has the world's largest unreinforced concrete dome, built nearly 2,000 years ago.
This city's first university, La Sapienza, was founded in 1303 and is one of the largest in Europe.

clues: This harbor city is known for its iconic opera house with sail-shaped roofs designed by Jørn Utzon.
It hosts the world's largest natural harbor and a famous New Year's Eve fireworks display over its harbor bridge.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build, 10 years longer than expected, and cost 14 times the original budget.
Sydney's Bondi Beach is one of the most famous beaches in the world, with lifeguards rescuing about 2,500 people per year.
trivia: Sydney Tower is the city's tallest structure at 309 meters and the second tallest observation tower in the Southern Hemisphere.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is nicknamed 'The Coathanger' due to its distinctive arch-based design and is the world's largest steel arch bridge.

clues: This city sits near some of the world's most famous triangular stone structures, built as tombs for pharaohs.
The world's longest river flows through this ancient metropolis, providing life to the surrounding desert.
fun_fact: The Great Pyramid of Giza, located on the outskirts of this city, is the only surviving structure of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.
Cairo's Al-Azhar University, founded in 970 CE, is one of the oldest continuously operating universities in the world.
trivia: The Egyptian Museum in this city contains more than 120,000 ancient Egyptian artifacts, including treasures from Tutankhamun's tomb.
Cairo's Khan el-Khalili bazaar has been operating since the 14th century and is still one of the world's greatest markets.

clues: This city is known for a massive statue of Christ with outstretched arms overlooking the bay from Corcovado Mountain.
It hosts the world's largest and most famous carnival celebration with samba parades and extravagant costumes.
fun_fact: The Christ the Redeemer statue is struck by lightning several times a year and has special lightning rods and a system of soapstone layers to protect it.
Copacabana Beach stretches for 2.5 miles and uses a distinctive black and white Portuguese wave pattern in its promenade designed by Roberto Burle Marx.
trivia: This city was once the capital of Portugal from 1808 to 1821, the only European capital to exist outside of Europe.
The Maracanã Stadium once held nearly 200,000 people for the 1950 World Cup final, the largest crowd ever at a sporting event.

clues: This city has more than 1,200 bridges crossing its 165 canals, which form concentric rings around the old city center.
Famous for its narrow houses, bicycle culture, and museums dedicated to artists like Van Gogh and Rembrandt.
fun_fact: Amsterdam has more bicycles than people, with an estimated 881,000 bikes for 821,000 residents.
Houses in Amsterdam are narrow because historically property taxes were based on the width of the building's facade, leading to the skinny canal houses.
trivia: Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport is built on land that was once at the bottom of the sea, reclaimed through the Dutch polder system.
The Anne Frank House is one of the city's most visited museums, preserving the hiding place where Anne Frank wrote her famous diary during World War II.

clues: This desert city is home to the world's tallest building (828 meters) and artificial islands shaped like palm trees.
Once a small fishing village, it's now known for luxury shopping, ultramodern architecture, and an indoor ski resort despite desert temperatures.
fun_fact: Police in this city drive luxury cars including Lamborghinis, Ferraris, and Bentleys to match the city's opulent image.
The Burj Khalifa is so tall that you can watch the sunset from the base, then take the elevator to the top and watch it set again about 2 minutes later.
trivia: This city has the world's largest choreographed fountain system, with water jets that shoot up to 500 feet in the air synchronized to music.
Gold is so common in the souks (markets) here that there's an entire market nicknamed 'The City of Gold' with about 10 tons of gold present at any time.

clues: This unique city is built on 118 small islands connected by over 400 bridges and separated by 150 canals.
Instead of roads, this city uses waterways and boats for transportation, with no cars allowed in its historic center.
fun_fact: Venice is sinking at a rate of 1-2 millimeters per year and experiences regular 'acqua alta' flooding.
The Venice Carnival dates back to the 12th century and is famous for its elaborate masks that historically allowed citizens to hide their identity and social status.
trivia: There are no cars or roads in Venice's historic center, making it the largest urban car-free area in Europe.
The city's famous gondolas are always painted black, by law (established after excessive decoration competition between nobles), except for those belonging to high government officials.

clues: This city has a famous clock tower called Elizabeth Tower, though many mistakenly call it by the name of its main bell.
It is home to Buckingham Palace and iconic red double-decker buses and telephone booths.
fun_fact: The London Underground is the world's first underground railway system, opened in 1863, and locals call it 'the Tube'.
There are more than 170 museums in London, many of which are free to visit, including the British Museum and National Gallery.
trivia: The River Thames has over 200 bridges crossing it within London, with Tower Bridge being the most famous, often confused with London Bridge.
Big Ben is actually the name of the main bell inside the Elizabeth Tower, not the tower or clock itself.

clues: A famous wall once divided this city into East and West sections for 28 years during the Cold War.
It is known for its techno music scene, street art, and the Brandenburg Gate monument.
fun_fact: Berlin has more bridges than Venice—over 1,700!
There are over 1,000 doner kebab shops in Berlin, more than in Istanbul, as the dish was popularized by Turkish immigrants.
trivia: Berlin's Zoologischer Garten is the oldest zoo in Germany (founded 1844) and houses one of the most comprehensive collections of species in the world.
The city's Brandenburg Gate was once a symbol of division but is now a symbol of unity and peace.

clues: This city is home to colorful onion-domed cathedrals, including St. Basil's Cathedral in Red Square.
It has one of the deepest and most ornate subway systems in the world, with stations decorated like palaces.
fun_fact: Moscow's Kremlin is the largest active fortress in Europe, serving as the official residence of the President.
The Moscow Metro stations are often called 'underground palaces' due to their luxurious design with mosaics, marble, and chandeliers.
trivia: Moscow spans over 2,500 square kilometers, making it one of the largest cities in the world by area and the largest city entirely in Europe.
The Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow is home to one of the world's oldest and most prestigious ballet companies, founded in 1776.

clues: This city uniquely straddles two continents: Europe and Asia, separated by the Bosphorus Strait.
It was formerly known as Byzantium and later Constantinople, serving as the capital of multiple empires.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar in this city has over 4,000 shops, 61 covered streets, and dates back to the 15th century as one of the world's oldest and largest covered markets.
Istanbul's Hagia Sophia has been a cathedral, a mosque, a museum, and now a mosque again in its 1,500-year history.
trivia: Tulips, often associated with the Netherlands, actually originated in Turkey and were sent to the Dutch from the Ottoman Empire.
The Bosphorus Strait is one of the world's busiest waterways, connecting the Black Sea to the Sea of Marmara and serving as a continental boundary.

clues: This city is home to the Royal Palace, the largest royal palace in Western Europe with over 3,000 rooms.
Its famous museum, the Prado, houses one of the world's finest collections of European art.
fun_fact: Madrid's coat of arms features a bear reaching for fruit from a strawberry tree, a statue of which can be found in the city's main square.
Madrid is the highest capital city in Europe at 650 meters above sea level, giving it a unique climate with hot summers and cold winters.
trivia: The oldest restaurant in the world according to Guinness World Records is in Madrid - Botín, founded in 1725 and mentioned in Ernest Hemingway's work.
Madrid's massive El Retiro Park was a royal property until the late 19th century and features a rare statue of the 'Fallen Angel' - one of the few public monuments of Lucifer in the world.

clues: This Mediterranean city is known for Antoni Gaudí's unique architecture, especially a massive unfinished cathedral.
It has a famous pedestrian street called La Rambla and hosted the 1992 Summer Olympics.
fun_fact: The Sagrada Família basilica has been under construction since 1882 and is not expected to be completed until 2026, the centenary of Gaudí's death.
Barcelona's grid layout in the Eixample district was revolutionary urban planning in the 19th century, with unique octagonal intersections.
trivia: Barcelona's Camp Nou is the largest soccer stadium in Europe with a capacity of over 99,000 spectators.
The city has 9 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, 7 of which were designed by Antoni Gaudí, including Park Güell and Casa Batlló.

clues: This coastal capital city is built on seven steep hills and is known for its vintage yellow trams.
Famous for its fado music, a melancholic genre, and pastéis de nata (custard tarts).
fun_fact: Lisbon was hit by one of the most powerful earthquakes in European history in 1755, which was followed by a tsunami and fires that destroyed 85% of the city.
The Vasco da Gama Bridge in Lisbon is one of the longest bridges in Europe at nearly 11 miles (17 km) long.
trivia: Lisbon is one of the oldest cities in Western Europe, predating London, Paris, and Rome by centuries.
The city's Alfama district survived the great earthquake and maintains its medieval layout with narrow winding streets.

clues: This ancient city is dominated by a hilltop citadel containing the remains of several ancient buildings including a famous temple to Athena.
Considered the birthplace of democracy, philosophy, and classical art forms in Western civilization.
fun_fact: Athens has been inhabited for at least 7,000 years, making it one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world.
The modern Athens Marathon follows the legendary route of Pheidippides, who ran from Marathon to Athens to announce the Greek victory over the Persians in 490 BCE.
trivia: The Acropolis is visible from almost anywhere in Athens and is illuminated at night to create a stunning landmark.
Despite its ancient history, Athens' metro system is one of the most modern in Europe and doubles as a museum with archaeological artifacts found during its construction displayed at stations.

clues: This city is known for its well-preserved medieval Old Town and the largest ancient castle complex in the world.
It has a famous astronomical clock from 1410 that gives an hourly show and a bridge lined with 30 statues.
fun_fact: Prague Castle covers an area of almost 70,000 square meters, making it the largest ancient castle complex in the world according to the Guinness Book of Records.
The city was largely untouched by World War II bombing, preserving its historic architecture spanning several centuries and styles.
trivia: Prague's Charles Bridge is lined with 30 baroque statues and was the only means of crossing the Vltava River until 1841.
The Prague Astronomical Clock has been measuring time since 1410, making it the third-oldest astronomical clock in the world and the oldest one still operating.

clues: This city is known as the 'City of Music' due to its musical legacy, home to Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss.
Famous for its imperial palaces, especially Schönbrunn, and its café culture with sachertorte chocolate cake.
fun_fact: Vienna's Central Cemetery has over 2.5 million tombs (more than the city's living population), including those of Beethoven, Schubert, Strauss, and Brahms.
The Spanish Riding School in Vienna has been training Lipizzaner horses in classical dressage for over 450 years.
trivia: Vienna has consistently been ranked as one of the world's most livable cities and was the first city to have a public housing program.
The Wiener Riesenrad, a giant Ferris wheel in the Prater amusement park, was built in 1897 and featured in films like 'The Third Man' and 'Before Sunrise'.

clues: This city is actually two cities divided by a river, united in 1873 with one side hilly and the other flat.
Famous for its thermal baths, including the Neo-Baroque Széchenyi Baths, the largest medicinal bath in Europe.
fun_fact: Budapest has the world's largest thermal water cave system and the second-largest synagogue in the world (the Dohány Street Synagogue).
The Hungarian Parliament Building in Budapest has 691 rooms and 20 kilometers (12.5 miles) of stairs, requiring 40 million bricks to build.
trivia: Rubik's Cube was invented by Hungarian architect Ernő Rubik, and Budapest has a museum dedicated to this famous puzzle.
This city has the oldest underground railway system in continental Europe, opened in 1896, second only to London's in age.

clues: This city's historic center was meticulously rebuilt after being destroyed in World War II, earning it the nickname 'Phoenix City.'
It is split by the Vistula River and features a mermaid with sword and shield as its symbol.
fun_fact: Warsaw's Old Town was so faithfully reconstructed after WWII that it was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site despite being largely built in the 1950s.
Marie Curie, the first person to win Nobel Prizes in two different scientific fields, was born in this city and studied at its Flying University.
trivia: The Palace of Culture and Science, a controversial gift from the Soviet Union, remains the tallest building in Poland at 237 meters.
Warsaw's Royal Lazienki Park features a famous monument to Chopin where free piano concerts are held every Sunday during summer.

clues: This city is known for its colorful harbor buildings in Nyhavn and a famous bronze statue of a fairytale character sitting on a rock.
Considered one of the world's most bicycle-friendly cities, with bikes outnumbering cars.
fun_fact: Copenhagen's Tivoli Gardens is one of the oldest amusement parks in the world, opened in 1843, and inspired Walt Disney to create Disneyland.
The Little Mermaid statue is relatively small (just 1.25 meters) and has been vandalized several times, including having her head removed twice.
trivia: The Copenhagen Opera House is one of the most expensive opera houses ever built, costing over $500 million, and was funded entirely as a gift to the city.
Christiania, a self-proclaimed autonomous neighborhood in the city, was established by squatters in 1971 and still operates with its own rules.

clues: This capital city is built on 14 islands connected by 57 bridges and is sometimes called 'Venice of the North.'
It's home to the Nobel Prize banquet and a museum dedicated to a famous pop group from the 1970s.
fun_fact: Stockholm's subway system is known as the world's longest art gallery, with over 90 of the 100 stations decorated with sculptures, mosaics, and paintings.
The Stockholm archipelago consists of about 30,000 islands and islets, many uninhabited, making it the largest archipelago in Sweden.
trivia: The Vasa Museum houses a nearly fully intact 17th-century warship that sank on its maiden voyage in 1628 and was salvaged in 1961.
ABBA The Museum allows visitors to virtually try on the band's costumes and sing with hologram versions of the Swedish pop stars.

clues: This waterfront capital has a famous white cathedral with green domes that dominates its skyline.
Known for its design scene, saunas, and an island fortress that's a UNESCO World Heritage site.
fun_fact: Helsinki has approximately 3 million saunas, averaging roughly one per household, and even has one inside Burger King.
The city was originally built as a rival to St. Petersburg when Finland was part of the Russian Empire in the early 19th century.
trivia: Helsinki's Temppeliaukio Church (Rock Church) is built directly into solid rock and is known for its excellent acoustics.
The city hosts Restaurant Day four times a year, when anyone can open a pop-up restaurant anywhere, from parks to living rooms.

clues: This capital city sits at the end of a fjord and is surrounded by forests and hills for skiing and hiking.
Home to the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony and a museum housing Viking ships over 1,000 years old.
fun_fact: Oslo is the only capital city in the world that has ski trails, forests, lakes, and beaches all within the city limits.
The Oslo Opera House has a sloped roof that visitors can walk on, designed to appear as if it rises from the water.
trivia: The Vigeland Sculpture Park contains over 200 sculptures in bronze, granite, and cast iron created by Gustav Vigeland, including the famous 'Angry Boy'.
Oslo City Hall, where the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony is held, has walls decorated with murals depicting Norwegian history, culture, and working life.

clues: This northernmost capital of a sovereign state is powered almost entirely by geothermal energy.
Its name means 'Smoky Bay' and it's dominated by the 73-meter-tall Hallgrímskirkja church.
fun_fact: In Reykjavik, it's possible to swim in naturally heated outdoor pools year-round, even when snow is on the ground.
The city doesn't have a mosquito population due to the climate's fluctuating temperatures.
trivia: Reykjavik uses geothermal water to heat sidewalks and streets to melt snow in winter.
The Imagine Peace Tower, a memorial to John Lennon from Yoko Ono, projects a beam of light vertically into the sky from the city each year.

clues: This city is divided by the River Liffey and is home to a famous dark beer brewery founded in 1759.
Its literary heritage includes writers like Joyce, Yeats, and Wilde, with a designated Cultural Quarter called Temple Bar.
fun_fact: Dublin's St. Patrick's Cathedral is the tallest and largest church in Ireland, and Jonathan Swift (author of 'Gulliver's Travels') was once its Dean.
The city has over 750 pubs, and its oldest, The Brazen Head, dates back to 1198.
trivia: The Book of Kells, an illuminated manuscript Gospel book created around 800 AD, is housed in Trinity College's Old Library.
Dublin's Ha'penny Bridge got its name from the halfpenny toll once charged to cross it when it opened in 1816.

clues: This city is the de facto capital of the European Union and known for its waffle-shaped waffle.
Famous for a small bronze fountain statue of a urinating boy that's often dressed in costumes.
fun_fact: The Brussels Grand Place contains the Town Hall, which has a spire that leans about 1 meter from the center - legend says the architect jumped from it upon discovering this flaw.
The city has over 1,000 varieties of beer and is famous for chocolate, with more than 500 chocolatiers.
trivia: The Atomium, a 102-meter tall structure resembling an iron crystal magnified 165 billion times, was built for the 1958 World's Fair.
Manneken Pis, the famous urinating boy statue, has over 900 costumes that are changed regularly according to a published schedule.

clues: This city sits at the northern tip of its eponymous lake and is the largest in its country despite not being the capital.
Known as a global center for banking and finance with a pristine old town divided by the Limmat River.
fun_fact: Zurich has the highest density of nightclubs in Switzerland and was home to the 'Dada' art movement, born in the Cabaret Voltaire in 1916.
The city has over 1,200 drinking fountains with clean, potable water - more public fountains than any other city in the world.
trivia: Zurich's Bahnhofstrasse is one of the world's most expensive shopping streets, built on top of the city's ancient moat.
James Joyce wrote much of his novel 'Ulysses' while living in Zurich and is buried in the city's Fluntern Cemetery.

clues: This city sits along the shores of Europe's largest Alpine lake and features a 140-meter-tall water fountain.
Known as a global hub for diplomacy, hosting the European headquarters of the United Nations and the Red Cross.
fun_fact: The Jet d'Eau fountain pumps 500 liters of water per second to a height of 140 meters and was originally created as a safety valve for hydraulic power.
The world's largest machine, the Large Hadron Collider, is located underneath this city at CERN, straddling the Swiss-French border.
trivia: Geneva was the center of the Protestant Reformation led by John Calvin in the 16th century.
The first Geneva Convention, establishing the rules of war and protection for the wounded, was signed in this city in 1864.

clues: This Bavarian city is known for its annual beer festival that attracts over 6 million visitors each year.
Home to BMW headquarters and the famous Glockenspiel clock tower in Marienplatz that tells the story of a royal wedding.
fun_fact: Munich's Englischer Garten (English Garden) is larger than New York's Central Park and contains a river with surfing waves.
The city's famous Oktoberfest originally celebrated a royal wedding in 1810 and has been canceled only 26 times in over 200 years.
trivia: The BMW Museum is shaped like a bowl of engine and showcases the company's technological developments alongside its car and motorcycle models.
FC Bayern Munich, one of the world's most successful soccer clubs, plays at Allianz Arena, which can change its entire external color.

clues: This city is a major financial hub with a skyline of skyscrapers that has earned it the nickname 'Mainhattan.'
It hosts the world's largest book fair and was the birthplace of Germany's most famous writer, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.
fun_fact: Frankfurt was the coronation city for Holy Roman Emperors from 1562 to 1792, with ceremonies held in its Imperial Cathedral.
The city was almost completely destroyed during World War II, with about 70% of its buildings reduced to rubble.
trivia: The Frankfurt Stock Exchange is one of the world's largest trading centers, represented by a bull and bear statue outside its building.
The city's signature dish is green sauce (Grüne Soße), made from seven herbs and traditionally served with hard-boiled eggs and potatoes.

clues: This northern Italian city is one of the world's fashion capitals and home to one of the largest Gothic cathedrals.
Leonardo da Vinci's 'The Last Supper' is housed in a convent here, and the city hosts one of the world's major opera houses.
fun_fact: Milan's Cathedral (Duomo) took nearly six centuries to complete and has more statues than any other building in the world - 3,400 in total.
The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is one of the world's oldest shopping malls, built in 1877 and known for its glass dome and mosaic floors.
trivia: La Scala Opera House is considered one of the leading opera and ballet theaters in the world, with some of the finest acoustics.
There's a tradition in Milan to spin your heel on the mosaic bull's testicles in the Galleria for good luck.

clues: This southern Italian city sits in the shadow of a famous active volcano and is the birthplace of pizza.
It has an extensive network of underground tunnels and cisterns dating back to Greek and Roman times.
fun_fact: Naples has the highest concentration of historical monuments and churches in the world, with over 500 churches in the historic center alone.
The original Neapolitan pizza (Pizza Margherita) was created in 1889 to honor Queen Margherita, with tomato, mozzarella, and basil representing the colors of the Italian flag.
trivia: The Naples National Archaeological Museum houses many of the best-preserved artifacts from Pompeii and Herculaneum.
The Veiled Christ sculpture in the Cappella Sansevero is so realistic that for years people believed the marble veil was real and later transformed to stone.

clues: This Scottish capital has an imposing castle on a volcanic rock and a famous annual arts festival in August.
Its historic Old Town and elegant Georgian New Town together form a UNESCO World Heritage site.
fun_fact: Edinburgh has 112 parks and more trees per person than any other UK city.
The city's medieval Old Town has a network of underground streets and chambers called the 'Real Mary King's Close' where residents lived until they were bricked up after a plague outbreak.
trivia: Edinburgh Castle sits atop an extinct volcano called Castle Rock and houses the Scottish Crown Jewels and the Stone of Destiny.
The Royal Mile is actually 1.12 miles long, connecting Edinburgh Castle with the Palace of Holyroodhouse, the Queen's official residence in Scotland.

clues: This Scottish city was once a major shipbuilding center and is known for its distinctive red sandstone Victorian architecture.
Famous for its vibrant music scene, it was designated a UNESCO City of Music in 2008.
fun_fact: Glasgow has the highest concentration of universities and colleges in Europe and the city's subway system is nicknamed 'the Clockwork Orange'.
The Glasgow School of Art, designed by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, was considered his masterpiece before being badly damaged by fires in 2014 and 2018.
trivia: The Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum houses Salvador Dalí's 'Christ of St. John of the Cross' and is one of Scotland's most popular attractions.
Glasgow's necropolis is a Victorian cemetery with around 50,000 individuals buried there, featuring elaborate monuments and mausoleums.

clues: This capital city sits along the Danube River and is the only national capital that borders two other countries.
Its skyline features a distinctive castle on a hill and a bridge with a UFO-shaped restaurant on top.
fun_fact: Bratislava is just 60 kilometers from Vienna, making them the closest capital cities in Europe (besides Rome and Vatican City).
The city's UFO observation deck and restaurant sits 95 meters above the Danube River on the SNP Bridge and can be reached by elevator in 45 seconds.
trivia: Bratislava Castle contains a branch of the Slovak National Museum and offers panoramic views of the city and neighboring countries.
The Old Town Hall is the oldest city hall in Slovakia and houses the city's oldest museum, with the entrance guarded by a cannonball from Napoleon's army embedded in the wall.

clues: This small capital city is built amid deep gorges cut by two rivers and features ancient fortress walls and casemates.
It is one of the three official capitals of the European Union and a major financial center despite its small size.
fun_fact: Luxembourg City's Bock Casemates are a 17 km network of underground tunnels carved out of solid rock that once sheltered thousands of soldiers and their equipment.
The city changes drastically in elevation, with the upper parts 70 meters higher than the lower districts in the gorges.
trivia: Luxembourg is one of the smallest countries in Europe but has the highest GDP per capita in the European Union.
The Grand Ducal Palace is the official residence of the Grand Duke of Luxembourg and is open to tourists during summer months.

clues: This city sits at the confluence of two major rivers and has a fortress that has been destroyed and rebuilt over 40 times.
Known for its vibrant nightlife and floating nightclubs called 'splavovi' along its riverbanks.
fun_fact: Belgrade Fortress has been destroyed over 40 times throughout history, making it one of the most contested pieces of real estate in Europe.
The city has been settled continuously since at least 7000 BC, making it one of the oldest human settlements in Europe.
trivia: Belgrade's Church of Saint Sava is one of the largest Orthodox churches in the world and one of the largest church buildings overall.
The House of Flowers is the mausoleum of former Yugoslav leader Josip Broz Tito, who ruled the country for 35 years.

clues: This capital city is divided into an Upper Town with medieval buildings and a Lower Town with 19th-century architecture.
Famous for its Museum of Broken Relationships and a stone gate with a miraculous painting that survived a fire.
fun_fact: Zagreb has a unique Museum of Broken Relationships displaying personal objects from failed relationships, which won the European Museum of the Year Award.
The city's Grič Cannon fires every day at noon from the Lotrščak Tower, a tradition dating back to the 19th century.
trivia: Zagreb Cathedral is the tallest building in Croatia and contains the tomb of Cardinal Alojzije Stepinac.
The city's Dolac Market has been the main trading place since the 1930s and is recognizable by its red umbrella stands.

clues: This small capital is known for its green initiatives and dragon symbols adorning its bridges and buildings.
The city center is traffic-free and overlooked by a medieval castle on a hill accessed by funicular.
fun_fact: Ljubljana has been car-free in its center since 2008, with free electric taxis called 'Kavalirs' (Gentle Helpers) available for those who need assistance.
The city's name is believed to derive from 'ljubljena,' meaning 'beloved,' or from 'ljubljanica,' the river that flows through it.
trivia: The Dragon Bridge is decorated with four dragon statues that according to legend, wag their tails when a virgin crosses.
Ljubljana Castle offers panoramic views of the city and houses a puppet museum, reflecting Slovenia's rich tradition of puppetry.

clues: This capital city sits at the foot of Vitosha Mountain and features gold-domed orthodox churches.
It has ancient Roman ruins visible in its metro stations and one of the largest Eastern Orthodox cathedrals in the world.
fun_fact: Sofia is among the few capital cities in Europe with a ski resort just 30 minutes away (Vitosha Mountain).
The city is built upon natural mineral springs, with public drinking fountains offering hot mineral water believed to have healing properties.
trivia: The Alexander Nevsky Cathedral is one of the largest Eastern Orthodox cathedrals in the world, built to honor Russian soldiers who died liberating Bulgaria in the Russo-Turkish War.
Sofia's Largo complex of Socialist Classicism buildings now houses the Bulgarian Presidency, with ancient Serdica ruins visible underneath through a glass floor.

clues: This city features the world's second-largest administrative building after the Pentagon, built by a communist dictator.
Once known as 'Little Paris' for its Belle Époque architecture and its own Arc de Triomphe.
fun_fact: The Palace of the Parliament is the world's second-largest administrative building, contains 3,500 tons of crystal, and has 1,100 rooms, many of which remain unused.
Bucharest's Cișmigiu Gardens, the city's oldest public garden, opened in 1854 and contains a Monte Carlo-style casino.
trivia: Bucharest has its own Arcul de Triumf (Arch of Triumph), modeled after the one in Paris and built after Romania's WWI victory.
The city's Old Town is home to Carturesti Carusel, one of the world's most beautiful bookstores, located in a restored 19th-century building.

clues: This Eastern European capital is known for its gold-domed churches and monasteries, particularly those in the Cave Monastery complex.
It features a massive titanium statue of a woman with shield and sword standing atop a war museum.
fun_fact: Kyiv is home to the deepest metro station in the world - Arsenalna - which is 105.5 meters below ground and takes over 5 minutes to reach by escalator.
The Motherland Monument in Kyiv stands 102 meters tall, weighs 560 tons, and was built as part of a Soviet war memorial complex in 1981.
trivia: Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra (the Monastery of the Caves) contains a network of underground tunnels with mummified monks' bodies naturally preserved for centuries.
Saint Sophia Cathedral contains the world's largest ensemble of frescoes and mosaics from the 11th century and is a UNESCO World Heritage site.

clues: This imperial city was built on swampland by a tsar who wanted a 'window to Europe' and features numerous canals and bridges.
Home to one of the world's largest art museums in a massive green palace along the Neva River.
fun_fact: Saint Petersburg has 342 bridges, 93 of which are drawbridges that open at night to let ships pass, potentially stranding people on the wrong side.
The city was built on swampland by Peter the Great starting in 1703, costing thousands of laborers' lives due to harsh conditions.
trivia: The Hermitage Museum houses over 3 million items, including the world's largest collection of paintings, and it would take 11 years to see each item for one minute.
During the summer months, Saint Petersburg experiences 'White Nights' when the sun barely sets, and the city hosts a famous arts and cultural festival.

clues: This city is known as the 'Third Capital of Russia' and features the country's only leaning tower within its white-walled kremlin.
Often called 'Russia's Istanbul' for its blend of Orthodox Christian and Muslim cultures, symbolized by churches and mosques standing side by side.
fun_fact: Kazan's kremlin contains both the Kul Sharif Mosque and the Annunciation Cathedral, symbolizing the peaceful coexistence of Islam and Orthodox Christianity.
The Söyembikä Tower within the kremlin leans even more than the Tower of Pisa, with a 1.98-meter deviation from vertical.
trivia: Kazan hosted the 2013 Summer Universiade, the 2015 World Aquatics Championships, and was one of the host cities for the 2018 FIFA World Cup.
The city's name means 'cooking pot' in Tatar, referring to its role as a cultural melting pot of Slavic and Turkic traditions.

clues: This massive Southeast Asian capital features the world's largest mosque by capacity and is sinking faster than any other big city.
Located on the northwest coast of Java, it was formerly known as Batavia during Dutch colonial rule.
fun_fact: Jakarta is sinking at an alarming rate of 25 cm per year in some areas due to groundwater extraction and the weight of its buildings.
The city is planning to relocate its capital functions to East Kalimantan by 2024 due to overcrowding and environmental issues.
trivia: The National Monument (Monas) in central Jakarta is 137 meters tall, topped with a flame coated in 35 kg of gold leaf.
Istiqlal Mosque is the largest mosque in Southeast Asia, can accommodate up to 200,000 worshippers, and is connected by a tunnel to the Jakarta Cathedral.

clues: This densely populated capital contains the oldest Chinatown in the world and was once surrounded by massive Spanish colonial walls.
Its historic walled city survived World War II bombings and features baroque churches and a famous sunset view over its bay.
fun_fact: Manila's Binondo district, established in 1594, is considered the oldest Chinatown in the world.
The city was once known as the 'Pearl of the Orient' and was the second most devastated city in World War II after Warsaw.
trivia: Intramuros, the historic walled city, contains Fort Santiago and San Agustin Church, one of the country's oldest stone churches and a UNESCO World Heritage site.
Manila Bay is famous for its spectacular sunsets, which have been described as one of the best in the world by travel writers.

clues: This city is known for its ornate shrines, canal network, and vibrant street life with floating markets.
Its official name is the longest city name in the world, starting with 'Krung Thep Mahanakhon' and continuing for over 40 more syllables.
fun_fact: Bangkok's full ceremonial name has 169 characters and is the longest place name in the world, typically abbreviated as 'Krung Thep' by locals.
The city has over 400 Buddhist temples (wats) and was built on a swamp, earning it the nickname 'Venice of the East' for its many canals.
trivia: The Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha) complex covers an area of 218,400 square meters and has been the royal residence since 1782.
Bangkok's Chatuchak Weekend Market is one of the world's largest with over 15,000 stalls spread across 35 acres.

clues: This Southeast Asian capital is known for its iconic twin towers that were once the world's tallest buildings.
Its name means 'muddy confluence' in Malay, referring to the meeting of the Klang and Gombak rivers where the city was founded.
fun_fact: The Petronas Towers, once the tallest buildings in the world (1998-2004), are connected by a sky bridge on the 41st and 42nd floors that is not actually attached to either tower but slides in and out.
Kuala Lumpur has a near-perfect year-round equatorial climate with constant temperatures and high humidity, making it one of the rainiest major cities in the world.
trivia: The Batu Caves just outside the city feature a 42.7-meter-high gold statue of Lord Murugan, the tallest statue of a Hindu deity in Malaysia.
KL Tower has a revolving restaurant that offers panoramic views of the city and stands on the fourth-highest telecommunications tower in the world.

clues: This Southeast Asian capital is known for its centuries-old architecture, lakes, and narrow streets in its Old Quarter.
It has a unique cultural landmark—a single stone pillar made to resemble a lotus blossom—and a preserved mausoleum with a communist leader.
fun_fact: Hanoi's Train Street features a working railway running so close to buildings that residents must move their belongings when trains pass through.
The city's Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum contains the preserved body of the Vietnamese revolutionary leader, which is sent to Russia annually for maintenance.
trivia: Hoan Kiem Lake in the center of Hanoi is associated with the legend of Emperor Lê Lợi receiving a magical sword from a turtle.
The Temple of Literature, built in 1070, was Vietnam's first university and is dedicated to Confucius, sages, and scholars.

clues: This city was formerly known as Saigon and features French colonial landmarks like a Notre-Dame cathedral made of materials from France.
Known for its chaotic traffic with millions of motorbikes and the network of tunnels used during wartime just outside the city.
fun_fact: Ho Chi Minh City has an estimated 8.5 million motorbikes, with around 1,000 new ones hitting the streets each day.
The Củ Chi tunnels outside the city form a 250-kilometer network of tunnels used during the Vietnam War, featuring trap doors, living areas, kitchens, and even hospitals.
trivia: The Saigon Central Post Office was designed by Gustave Eiffel (of Eiffel Tower fame) and still functions as a post office today.
The Bến Thành Market was built in 1870 and is recognized by its clock tower, with over 3,000 stalls selling everything from food to souvenirs.

clues: This island city-state features a giant observation wheel, a hotel with an infinity pool on its boat-shaped rooftop, and a statue of a lion-fish hybrid.
Known for its strict cleanliness laws, multicultural neighborhoods, and futuristic Gardens by the Bay with supertrees.
fun_fact: Singapore's Gardens by the Bay features 18 'Supertrees' that are vertical gardens up to 50 meters tall and generate solar power.
The city-state has a fine for not flushing public toilets, and the sale of chewing gum is restricted after it was used to vandalize the Mass Rapid Transit system.
trivia: The iconic Merlion statue with the head of a lion and body of a fish represents Singapore's original name Singapura ('lion city') and its history as a fishing village.
Marina Bay Sands hotel has the world's largest rooftop infinity pool, 57 stories above ground level and 150 meters long.

clues: This Asian capital mixes modern skyscrapers with traditional temples and palaces surrounded by mountains.
Known for its technologically advanced infrastructure, including the world's fastest internet and a massive underground shopping mall.
fun_fact: Seoul's Lotte World Tower is the 5th tallest building in the world and contains the world's highest glass-bottomed observation deck.
The city has one of the world's most extensive and advanced subway systems, with Wi-Fi, heated seats, and cellphone service even underground.
trivia: Gyeongbokgung Palace, built in 1395, was the main royal palace of the Joseon dynasty and features a changing of the guard ceremony in traditional costumes.
Namsan Seoul Tower stands 236m high on Namsan Mountain and features 'love locks' where couples attach padlocks as symbols of their commitment.

clues: This capital city is home to the world's largest palace complex with 9,999 rooms and an emperor who was considered the 'Son of Heaven.'
Just outside the city is an ancient defensive structure built to keep out Mongol invaders that stretches for thousands of kilometers.
fun_fact: The Forbidden City has 9,999 rooms, deliberately one room short of 10,000 because only heaven could have 10,000 rooms according to ancient belief.
Beijing's Central Business District contains the world's largest building by floor area—the New Century Global Center, which could fit 20 Sydney Opera Houses inside.
trivia: The Great Wall's Mutianyu section near Beijing dates back to the 6th century and was rebuilt in the 16th century during the Ming Dynasty.
The Temple of Heaven's Echo Wall allows whispers to travel clearly from one end to the other over several meters due to its unique acoustic properties.

clues: This Chinese metropolis features a distinctive skyline with the Oriental Pearl TV Tower and the world's second-tallest building.
Known for its historical waterfront area called the Bund, with colonial-era buildings facing ultra-modern skyscrapers across the river.
fun_fact: Shanghai Tower, the city's tallest building at 632 meters, has the world's fastest elevator, traveling at 20.5 meters per second (74 km/h).
The city has the world's first commercial maglev train, which reaches speeds of 430 km/h, connecting Pudong Airport to the outskirts in 8 minutes.
trivia: The Bund features 52 buildings of various architectural styles, including Gothic, Baroque, and Art Deco, once housing powerful Western banks and trading houses.
Yu Garden was built in the 16th century during the Ming Dynasty and features a famous zigzag bridge designed to confuse evil spirits, who were believed to travel only in straight lines.

clues: This high-rise city is known for its dense skyline of skyscrapers set against mountains and a harbor crossed by traditional junk boats.
Famous for its Symphony of Lights show, displaying synchronized lights and lasers from more than 40 buildings each evening.
fun_fact: Hong Kong has more skyscrapers (buildings over 150m) than any other city in the world – over 300 – more than twice as many as New York City.
The city's Peak Tram, operating since 1888, is one of the world's oldest funicular railways and climbs so steeply that buildings appear to lean at impossible angles.
trivia: The world's longest outdoor covered escalator system in Hong Kong's Mid-Levels stretches over 800 meters and rises 135 meters through the city.
Rent in Hong Kong is so expensive that 'cage homes' exist – tiny living spaces as small as 1.5 square meters where people live in stacked metal cages.

clues: This east Asian capital features a bamboo-shaped skyscraper that held the title of world's tallest building from 2004 to 2010.
Known for its night markets, hot springs, and a museum housing treasures brought from mainland China.
fun_fact: Taipei 101 has a 728-ton steel pendulum damper sphere visible to visitors that acts as a tuned mass damper, stabilizing the building during typhoons and earthquakes.
The city's metro system is so clean that many stations have elaborate art installations, and eating or drinking on trains incurs a fine of up to NT$7500 (approx. $250).
trivia: The National Palace Museum houses over 700,000 ancient Chinese artifacts and works of art, spanning 8,000 years of Chinese history.
Taipei's Shilin Night Market is one of the largest and most famous night markets in Taiwan, with over 500 food stalls and shops.

clues: This former Portuguese colony is known as the 'Las Vegas of Asia' for its massive casinos and luxury hotels.
Features a distinctive fusion of Chinese and Portuguese architecture, cuisine, and culture, with colonial buildings alongside temples.
fun_fact: Macau has the highest population density in the world, with around 21,400 people per square kilometer.
The city generates more gambling revenue than Las Vegas, with seven times the gambling revenue of the entire Vegas Strip.
trivia: The ruins of St. Paul's, the remains of a 17th-century complex including what was originally the largest Catholic church in Asia, is one of Macau's most famous landmarks.
The Macau Tower's Skyjump holds the Guinness World Record for the highest commercial bungee jump at 233 meters.

clues: This capital city features a massive war memorial gate inspired by the Arc de Triomphe and a tower resembling the Qutub Minar.
Planned by British architects in the early 20th century with wide avenues, it sits adjacent to the older part of the city.
fun_fact: New Delhi is technically only a small part of the larger Delhi metropolis and became India's capital in 1931, replacing Calcutta (now Kolkata).
Agrasen ki Baoli is a 14th-century stepwell in the heart of the city that has 103 steps leading down to the water and is believed to be haunted.
trivia: India Gate is a 42-meter-high war memorial commemorating the 70,000 Indian soldiers who lost their lives fighting for the British Army in World War I.
New Delhi's Connaught Place is one of the largest commercial and financial centers in Delhi, built in a circular pattern with Georgian architecture.

clues: This coastal city was formerly known as Bombay and features a grand railway station and iconic Gateway monument.
Home to Bollywood, the world's largest film industry by number of films produced, and the Dharavi slum featured in 'Slumdog Millionaire'.
fun_fact: Mumbai's Dhobi Ghat is an enormous open-air laundromat where thousands of washermen (dhobis) clean clothes in concrete wash pens daily, visible from passing trains.
The city's dabbawalas deliver 200,000 home-cooked lunches daily with such precision that they've earned a Six Sigma efficiency rating and are studied at business schools.
trivia: Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus (formerly Victoria Terminus) is a UNESCO World Heritage site and one of the busiest railway stations in India, serving 3 million commuters daily.
The Gateway of India was built to commemorate the visit of King George V and Queen Mary in 1911, but they only saw a cardboard model as construction finished in 1924.

clues: This southern Indian city is known as the 'Silicon Valley of India' for its IT industry and startups.
Once called the 'Garden City' for its many parks and green spaces, including a botanical garden established in 1760.
fun_fact: Bangalore has the highest number of pubs in Asia, earning it the nickname 'Pub Capital of India,' with over 900 establishments.
The city sits at an elevation of 920 meters, giving it one of the most pleasant climates in India despite being relatively close to the equator.
trivia: Bangalore Palace was built in 1887 by the Wadiyar dynasty and was modeled after England's Windsor Castle.
The Indian Space Research Organisation's headquarters is located in Bangalore, managing India's space program including the Mars Orbiter Mission.

clues: This southern Indian coastal city was formerly known as Madras and is known for its beaches along the Bay of Bengal.
Famous for its classical Carnatic music, Bharatanatyam dance, and December Music Season festival.
fun_fact: Chennai has the second-longest urban beach in the world, Marina Beach, stretching 13 kilometers along the Bay of Bengal.
The city is sometimes called the 'Detroit of India' because it produces nearly 40% of India's auto parts and vehicles.
trivia: Fort St. George, built in 1644, was the first English fortress in India and now houses the Tamil Nadu legislative assembly.
Chennai's Kapaleeshwarar Temple is dedicated to Lord Shiva and features a 40-meter gopuram (gateway tower) with intricate carvings of Hindu deities.

clues: This coastal city sits beneath a famous flat-topped mountain and near the point where two oceans meet.
Known for its harbor, beaches, and nearby wineries, as well as the historic prison island visible from its shores.
fun_fact: Cape Town is home to Table Mountain, which has over 2,200 species of plants, more than exist in the entire United Kingdom.
The city lies near Cape Point, but contrary to popular belief, this is not where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet—that's actually at Cape Agulhas, 150km southeast.
trivia: Robben Island, where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years, is now a museum accessible by boat from Cape Town's V&A Waterfront.
The colorful houses of the Bo-Kaap neighborhood were originally leased to enslaved people from Malaysia, Indonesia, and other parts of Africa, painted bright colors as an expression of freedom.

clues: This city was founded during a gold rush and is not a national or provincial capital, though it's the largest city in its country.
Known for its mining history, financial district with skyscrapers, and the nearby Cradle of Humankind archaeological site.
fun_fact: Johannesburg is the world's largest city not built on a major body of water like a river, lake, or coastline.
The city has over 10 million trees, creating one of the world's largest man-made forests, visible from space when in leaf.
trivia: The Constitution Hill complex includes the former prison where both Nelson Mandela and Mahatma Gandhi were held, now transformed into a living museum.
Gold Reef City theme park is built on an old gold mine that closed in 1971 and offers underground mine tours to show visitors how gold was extracted.

clues: This North African port city features one of the world's largest mosques with a 210-meter minaret overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.
Made famous by the 1942 film of the same name starring Humphrey Bogart, though the movie was not actually filmed there.
fun_fact: Hassan II Mosque's minaret is the tallest religious structure in the world and features a laser at the top directed toward Mecca.
Despite being the setting for the famous film 'Casablanca,' no scenes were actually shot in the city—the entire movie was filmed in Hollywood.
trivia: Casablanca is Morocco's largest city and main port, handling more than 21 million tons of cargo annually.
The city's Habous Quarter was built by the French in the 1930s to resemble a traditional Moroccan medina but with modern amenities.

clues: This ancient city is known for its massive market square filled with entertainers and food stalls that transforms at night.
Famous for its maze-like medina (old city) with narrow streets, surrounded by reddish walls that give the city its nickname.
fun_fact: Marrakech is known as the 'Red City' due to the reddish-pink hue of its buildings and walls, made from local clay.
Jemaa el-Fnaa square transforms completely from day to night, changing from a trading area to a massive open-air restaurant and entertainment venue.
trivia: The Majorelle Garden was restored by fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, who loved the city so much that his ashes were scattered there after his death.
Marrakech's medina contains over 3,000 derbs (alleyways), many too narrow for cars, forming one of the world's largest car-free urban areas.

clues: This African capital has a national park within its city limits where lions, giraffes, and rhinos roam with the city skyline as backdrop.
Known as the 'Green City in the Sun' and features the home of 'Out of Africa' author Karen Blixen.
fun_fact: Nairobi is the only major city in the world with a national park within its boundaries where wild lions, rhinos, and giraffes roam freely.
The city's name comes from the Maasai phrase 'Enkare Nairobi,' which means 'place of cool waters,' though it started as a railway depot in 1899.
trivia: The Giraffe Centre allows visitors to feed endangered Rothschild's giraffes from a raised platform at eye level with the animals.
Nairobi National Museum houses the complete skeleton of Turkana Boy, a 1.6-million-year-old fossil of Homo erectus.

clues: This massive African city spans mainland and islands connected by bridges, with many neighborhoods built on reclaimed land.
Known for its energetic nightlife, Afrobeat music scene pioneered by Fela Kuti, and its massive tech startup ecosystem.
fun_fact: Lagos is one of the fastest-growing cities in the world and may become the world's largest city by population by the end of the century.
The city's name means 'lakes' in Portuguese, given by Portuguese explorers in the 15th century because of the many lagoons and waterways.
trivia: Lagos was Nigeria's capital until 1991 when the government relocated the administrative center to Abuja.
The city's New Afrika Shrine is a live music venue established by Femi Kuti in honor of his father Fela Kuti's original The Shrine, a center of Afrobeat music.

clues: This West African capital features a large Independence Square with an iconic Black Star gate and eternal flame.
Known for its colorful open-air markets, including Makola Market, and gold-named coastal castles that were once slave forts.
fun_fact: Accra's Labadi Beach is one of the most popular beaches in Ghana, with drumming and dance performances on weekend evenings.
The city's distinctive fantasy coffins, shaped like everything from cars to mobile phones to fish, are famous works of art intended to represent the deceased's profession or passion.
trivia: Independence Square in Accra contains the Independence Arch, Black Star Gate, and Eternal Flame of African Liberation lit by the first president, Kwame Nkrumah.
Jamestown Lighthouse, built in the 1930s, offers panoramic views of the oldest district of Accra, known for its fishing community and colonial architecture.

clues: This West African port city sits on the Cap-Vert peninsula, the westernmost point of continental Africa.
Known for its vibrant music scene, French colonial architecture, and a giant African Renaissance monument taller than the Statue of Liberty.
fun_fact: Dakar hosts the finish line of the famous Paris-Dakar Rally, though since 2009 the race has been held in South America and Saudi Arabia due to security concerns.
The African Renaissance Monument is the tallest statue in Africa at 49 meters, slightly taller than the Statue of Liberty, and was built by North Korean workers.
trivia: Gorée Island just off Dakar's coast was one of the largest slave-trading centers on the African coast from the 15th to 19th centuries.
Dakar's Pink Lake (Lac Rose) gets its distinctive color from Dunaliella salina algae and has a salt content comparable to the Dead Sea.

clues: This capital city sits at an elevation of 2,355 meters, making it one of the highest major cities in Africa.
Home to the African Union headquarters and known for its coffee culture—the plant is native to this country.
fun_fact: Addis Ababa means 'New Flower' in Amharic and was founded in 1886 by Emperor Menelik II after his wife Taytu Betul discovered hot springs there.
The city has a unique time system where 6 AM is considered 0:00, as Ethiopians start counting hours at sunrise, not midnight.
trivia: The National Museum of Ethiopia houses the fossilized remains of 'Lucy,' a 3.2-million-year-old hominid discovered in 1974.
Mercato in Addis Ababa is the largest open-air market in Africa, covering several square miles with tens of thousands of people shopping daily.

clues: This East African port city was once the capital of its country and its name means 'Haven of Peace' in Arabic.
Known for its Tingatinga painting style, German colonial buildings, and being a gateway to safari parks and Zanzibar.
fun_fact: Dar es Salaam was the capital of Tanzania until 1974 when the government announced plans to move to Dodoma, though many government offices remain in Dar.
The city features a unique architectural style called 'colonial modernism,' blending European styles with tropical adaptations like deep verandas.
trivia: The National Museum of Tanzania houses important fossils from Olduvai Gorge, where some of the oldest known human ancestral remains were discovered.
Kariakoo Market is the main market of Dar es Salaam, with its name derived from 'carry corps', as it was the site of an old colonial carrier corps.

clues: This sprawling capital was built on the ruins of an ancient lake city with canals and is slowly sinking due to groundwater extraction.
Home to the second-largest city square in the world after Moscow's Red Square and surrounded by volcanic mountains.
fun_fact: Mexico City is built on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the ancient Aztec capital that was situated on an island in Lake Texcoco, and parts of the city are sinking at a rate of up to 20 cm per year.
The city has more museums than any other city in the world—over 150—including one dedicated entirely to chocolate.
trivia: Chapultepec Park is one of the largest city parks in the Western Hemisphere at 1,695 acres, twice the size of New York's Central Park.
The Metropolitan Cathedral took nearly 250 years to build and features a mix of architectural styles including Gothic, Baroque, and Neoclassical.

clues: This city is considered the birthplace of mariachi music and the wide-brimmed sombrero hat.
Known as Mexico's Silicon Valley for its tech industry and the city where tequila and the Mexican hat dance originated.
fun_fact: Guadalajara hosts the International Book Fair (FIL), the largest Spanish language book fair in the world and second largest book fair overall after Frankfurt.
The city contains Hospicio Cabañas, a UNESCO World Heritage site with murals by José Clemente Orozco, including 'El Hombre de Fuego' (The Man of Fire).
trivia: The Guadalajara Cathedral's twin yellow-tiled towers are an iconic part of the city's skyline, built over 50 years in the 16th-17th centuries.
Nearby Lake Chapala is Mexico's largest freshwater lake and has become a popular retirement destination for Americans and Canadians.

clues: This industrial northern Mexican city is surrounded by mountains, including one shaped like a saddle.
Known for its manufacturing, particularly steel and beer, and as one of the wealthiest cities in Latin America.
fun_fact: Monterrey's iconic Cerro de la Silla (Saddle Hill) has a distinctive saddle-shaped silhouette that is featured on the state's license plates.
The city houses the Macroplaza, one of the world's largest urban squares at 99 acres, with the majority developed in the 1980s.
trivia: MARCO (Museo de Arte Contemporáneo) is housed in a distinctive red building designed by Ricardo Legorreta and features national and international contemporary art.
Fundidora Park was built on the site of a former steel foundry that was Latin America's first integrated steel company and now contains an industrial museum.

clues: This high-altitude capital sits at 2,640 meters above sea level, making it one of the highest major cities in the world.
Known for its colonial La Candelaria district, gold museum, and a church built into a salt mine nearby.
fun_fact: Bogotá has over 5,000 parks and green spaces, including the Bogotá Botanical Garden, which focuses on Andean ecosystem conservation.
Every Sunday and holiday, the city closes over 120 km of roads to cars for Ciclovía, when up to 2 million people take to the streets on bicycles.
trivia: The Gold Museum (Museo del Oro) contains over 55,000 pieces of gold and other materials from pre-Hispanic cultures, the largest collection of gold artifacts in the world.
The Salt Cathedral of Zipaquirá, located in a salt mine near Bogotá, has 14 small chapels representing the Stations of the Cross, all carved out of the halite rock.

clues: This coastal capital rarely receives rain despite being surrounded by desert and is known for its Spanish colonial architecture.
Famous for its food scene, including ceviche, and pre-Inca ruins scattered throughout the city.
fun_fact: Lima is one of the driest world capitals, receiving just 0.31 inches of rain annually, though it experiences high humidity and fog during winter.
The city's stray cat population in Kennedy Park (Parque Kennedy) has become a tourist attraction, with volunteers caring for over 100 cats that roam freely.
trivia: Huaca Pucllana is a massive adobe and clay pyramid built between 200 and 700 AD, located in the middle of the Miraflores district.
Lima's Historic Centre is a UNESCO World Heritage site featuring colonial architecture like the Archbishop's Palace, Government Palace, and Cathedral of Lima.

clues: This capital city is surrounded by snow-capped Andes mountains and features a distinctive white spire tower.
Known for its neoclassical architecture, wine regions nearby, and as one of the largest cities in the Americas.
fun_fact: Santiago's Grand Torre Santiago is the tallest building in Latin America at 300 meters and 64 floors.
The city has the largest pool in the world—the Crystal Lagoon at San Alfonso del Mar resort—over 1 km long and holding 66 million gallons of water.
trivia: La Moneda Palace, the seat of the President of Chile, was built as a mint in 1805 and was bombed during the 1973 military coup that overthrew Salvador Allende.
Santiago's Metropolitan Park (Parque Metropolitano) is one of the largest urban parks in Latin America, with the summit of San Cristóbal Hill offering panoramic views of the city.

clues: This South American capital is known as the 'Paris of South America' for its European architecture and wide boulevards.
Famous for tango dancing, steakhouses called parrillas, and colorful houses in the La Boca neighborhood.
fun_fact: Buenos Aires has more bookstores per capita than any other city in the world—over 700—including El Ateneo Grand Splendid, a theater converted into a bookstore.
The city's Recoleta Cemetery contains over 6,400 statues, sarcophagi, coffins, and crypts, including Eva Perón's grave, in elaborate architectural styles.
trivia: Teatro Colón is considered one of the best opera houses in the world for its acoustics and ranks among the top five concert venues globally.
The Obelisco de Buenos Aires, built in 1936, commemorates the city's 400th anniversary and stands at the site where the Argentine flag was first raised in Buenos Aires.

clues: This capital city features the longest continuous sidewalk in the world along its coastline and a famous old town.
Known for its Art Deco and colonial architecture, mate tea culture, and a massive carnival celebration second only to Rio.
fun_fact: Montevideo's Rambla is the longest continuous sidewalk in the world, stretching 22 kilometers along the coastline of the Río de la Plata.
The city has a massive underground network of tunnels built during colonial times, some of which are believed to have been used to smuggle contraband.
trivia: The Palacio Salvo was once the tallest building in South America and was originally designed to be a hotel with a lighthouse on top.
Montevideo's Carnival is the longest in the world, lasting over 40 days with parades featuring candombe drumming groups and murga musical theatre.

clues: This South American capital sits in a valley surrounded by mountains, with a famous national park and mountain cable car.
Known for its modern architecture, oil wealth, and hillside barrios with colorful houses.
fun_fact: Caracas has the world's cheapest gasoline due to government subsidies, sometimes costing less than a penny per gallon.
The city's cable car to Ávila Mountain, built in the 1950s, was once the longest and highest in the world and offers views of both the city and Caribbean Sea.
trivia: The Central University of Venezuela campus is a UNESCO World Heritage site, featuring art by 28 of the most important artists of the country integrated into its architecture.
Caracas is the birthplace of Simón Bolívar, the revolutionary leader who helped establish the independence of Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela.

clues: This capital city sits high in the Andean foothills at an elevation of 2,850 meters and is bisected by the equator.
Known for its well-preserved colonial center with 16th-century churches and monasteries, one covered in gold leaf inside.
fun_fact: Quito was the first city to be declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1978 (along with Kraków, Poland) for having the best-preserved historic center in Latin America.
The Middle of the World Monument (Mitad del Mundo) marks where the equator passes through, though modern GPS shows it's actually about 240 meters off.
trivia: The Church of the Society of Jesus (La Compañía de Jesús) took 160 years to build and has an interior covered with approximately seven tons of gold leaf.
The TelefériQo cable car takes visitors up to 4,100 meters on the east side of Pichincha Volcano, offering spectacular views of the city and surrounding volcanoes.

clues: This Caribbean capital is known for its vintage American cars, Spanish colonial architecture, and a famous seafront boulevard.
Famous for its connection to Ernest Hemingway, mojito cocktails, and cigar factories.
fun_fact: Havana's classic American cars from the 1950s remain because of the U.S. embargo imposed in 1960, which prevented the import of new American cars and parts.
The city has a 5-mile sea wall called the Malecón that serves as a social hub where locals gather to fish, socialize, and romance, known as 'the world's longest sofa'.
trivia: Old Havana (Habana Vieja) contains over 900 historical buildings and was declared a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1982.
Hemingway's former home, Finca Vigía, is now a museum where he wrote 'For Whom the Bell Tolls' and 'The Old Man and the Sea'.

clues: This Caribbean capital features a massive 16th-century citadel and blue cobblestone streets in its old town.
Known for its Spanish colonial architecture painted in bright colors and being the second-oldest European-established city in the Americas.
fun_fact: San Juan's streets in the Old Town are paved with blue cobblestones called adoquines, made from furnace slag from Spanish iron foundries and brought as ballast on ships.
El Morro fortress has walls up to 140 feet thick and survived numerous attacks over 400 years, including from Sir Francis Drake and the Dutch.
trivia: The Bacardí Rum Factory in San Juan is the largest premium rum distillery in the world, capable of producing 100,000 liters per day.
The Cathedral of San Juan Bautista contains the tomb of Spanish explorer Ponce de León and is the second-oldest cathedral in the Americas.

clues: This Central American capital sits at the Pacific entrance to a famous canal and features a historic district contrasting with modern skyscrapers.
Known for its banking sector, ruins of the original city destroyed by pirates, and being the only capital city with a rainforest within its limits.
fun_fact: Panama City is the only capital city in the world that has a rainforest within its city limits—the Metropolitan Natural Park houses 227 bird species, 45 mammal species, and 65 reptile species.
The city was founded in 1519, destroyed by Captain Henry Morgan in 1671, and then rebuilt two years later 5 miles from the original location.
trivia: The Panama Canal generates about $2 billion annually for the country, with ships paying tolls based on their size and cargo—the highest toll ever paid was $1.13 million by the cruise ship Norwegian Pearl.
Panama Viejo, the remains of the original city, is a UNESCO World Heritage site along with the historic district of Casco Viejo, which features colonial architecture from the late 17th century.

clues: This Central American capital sits in a lush valley surrounded by volcanoes and coffee plantations.
Known for its neoclassical National Theatre, Pre-Columbian Gold Museum, and vibrant Central Market.
fun_fact: San José is one of the youngest capital cities in Latin America, becoming Costa Rica's capital in 1823 after independence from Spain.
The city's National Theatre is considered one of the finest historical buildings in Central America and was partially funded by a tax on coffee exports in the 1890s.
trivia: The Pre-Columbian Gold Museum contains one of the largest collections of pre-Columbian gold artifacts in the Americas, with more than 1,600 pieces dating from 500 AD.
San José's Central Market has been operating since 1880 and occupies an entire block, with narrow alleys housing over 200 shops, stalls, and sodas (small restaurants).

clues: This administrative capital is the highest de facto capital city in the world at over 3,600 meters above sea level.
Known for its aerial cable car system, indigenous markets, and dramatic setting in a canyon beneath snow-capped mountains.
fun_fact: La Paz has the world's largest urban cable car system, Mi Teleférico, with 10 lines spanning 33 km that help residents navigate the city's steep terrain.
Due to the altitude, soccer games played in the city's Hernando Siles Stadium were banned by FIFA in 2007, though the ban was later lifted after protests.
trivia: The Witches' Market (Mercado de las Brujas) sells traditional remedies, potions, dried llama fetuses, and fortune-telling services, primarily used in Aymara rituals.
Valley of the Moon, just outside the city, features bizarre lunar-like landscapes created by erosion of the clay-rich mountain.

clues: This subtropical capital sits along the Paraguay River and is one of the oldest cities in South America.
Known for its colonial and neoclassical buildings, including López Palace and the Panteón Nacional de los Héroes.
fun_fact: Asunción was founded on August 15, 1537, which is why it's known as 'Mother of Cities'—many expeditions departed from here to found other cities in the region.
The city's unusual street numbering system increases by 100 with each block, so house #349 would be on the 3rd block of the street.
trivia: The Panteón Nacional de los Héroes houses the remains of Paraguay's great heroes, including José Gaspar Rodríguez de Francia and Francisco Solano López.
Asunción's Casa de la Independencia is where Paraguay's independence from Spain was secretly planned in 1811, preserved as it was in the early 19th century.

clues: This Caribbean capital sits on a natural harbor protected by a long sandbar and was once a haven for pirates.
Known as the birthplace of reggae music, with museums dedicated to Bob Marley and a famous recording studio.
fun_fact: Kingston was founded in 1692 after an earthquake destroyed the nearby city of Port Royal, then known as the 'wickedest city on Earth' for its pirate population.
The city's Trench Town neighborhood, immortalized in Bob Marley's songs, was originally a housing project built in the 1940s that became the cradle of reggae music.
trivia: The Bob Marley Museum was the reggae superstar's home from 1975 until his death in 1981 and still has bullet holes in the walls from a 1976 assassination attempt.
Devon House, built in 1881 by Jamaica's first black millionaire, George Stiebel, is famous for its ice cream and represents the cultural diversity of 19th-century Jamaica.

clues: This Caribbean capital features a large park called the Savannah with a collection of historic mansions known as the Magnificent Seven.
Known for hosting one of the world's most famous carnival celebrations and calypso music.
fun_fact: Port of Spain's Queen's Park Savannah is said to have the world's largest roundabout at 3.5 km around.
The city's carnival dates back to the 18th century when French plantation owners held masquerade balls; after emancipation, former slaves transformed it with African traditions and calypso music.
trivia: The Magnificent Seven are a group of grand mansions along the western edge of Queen's Park Savannah, built between 1902 and 1910 in various architectural styles.
The Red House, the seat of Parliament, was the site of a hostage crisis in 1990 when 114 members of the Jamaat al Muslimeen attempted to overthrow the government.

clues: This multicultural city features a famous needle-like tower and sits on the shores of one of the Great Lakes.
Known for its diverse neighborhoods, underground shopping concourse, and being Canada's largest city.
fun_fact: Toronto has the world's longest street—Yonge Street—which stretches 1,896 km (though this claim is debated as it includes the entire Highway 11).
The city has the largest underground pedestrian system in North America—PATH—connecting 30 km of shopping, services, and entertainment.
trivia: The CN Tower was the world's tallest freestanding structure from 1976 until 2007 and features a glass floor 342 meters above ground.
Toronto's Kensington Market has been a hub for successive waves of immigrants since the early 20th century and is now a National Historic Site.

clues: This Pacific coastal city is surrounded by mountains and consistently ranked among the world's most livable cities.
Known for its film industry (nicknamed 'Hollywood North'), outdoor lifestyle, and large urban park with a seawall.
fun_fact: Vancouver has been the filming location for countless movies and TV shows, earning it the nickname 'Hollywood North,' with over 65 productions being filmed there at any given time.
The city's Stanley Park is about 10% larger than New York's Central Park, with a 8.8 km seawall that takes 2-3 hours to walk around.
trivia: The Capilano Suspension Bridge stretches 137 meters across and 70 meters above the Capilano River, originally built in 1889 with hemp rope and cedar planks.
Vancouver's Gastown Steam Clock is one of the few working steam clocks in the world, though it's actually powered mostly by electricity with the steam used mainly for show.

clues: This island city features a hill in its center called 'Royal Mountain' and is the second-largest French-speaking city in the world after Paris.
Known for its distinctive blend of European and North American culture, underground city, and numerous festivals.
fun_fact: Montreal has over 32 km of underground pedestrian walkways connecting shopping malls, apartment and office buildings, hotels, and metro stations, developed to avoid the harsh winter weather.
The city has more restaurants per capita than any other city in North America and is considered one of the gastronomic capitals of the continent.
trivia: The Notre-Dame Basilica, built between 1824 and 1829, features a stunning interior with deep blue ceilings decorated with golden stars.
Montreal hosts the world's largest jazz festival (Festival International de Jazz de Montréal), comedy festival (Just for Laughs), and one of the largest fireworks competitions.

clues: This western Canadian city is known for its annual rodeo event and proximity to the Rocky Mountains.
Famous for its cowboy culture, oil industry, and an observation tower resembling a space needle.
fun_fact: Calgary's +15 Skyway network is the world's most extensive pedestrian skywalk system, with over 18 km of walkways 15 feet above street level connecting buildings downtown.
The city hosted the 1988 Winter Olympics, made famous by the Jamaican bobsled team that inspired the movie 'Cool Runnings'.
trivia: The Calgary Stampede, known as 'The Greatest Outdoor Show on Earth,' has been held annually since 1912 and features one of the world's richest rodeo competitions.
The Calgary Tower, built in 1968, was the tallest structure in the city until 1984 and features a rotating restaurant that makes a full rotation every 45 minutes at lunchtime.

clues: This capital city sits at the confluence of three rivers and features Gothic Revival parliament buildings on a scenic hill.
Known for its canal that becomes the world's largest naturally frozen skating rink in winter and changing of the guard ceremony.
fun_fact: The Rideau Canal becomes the world's largest naturally frozen skating rink in winter, stretching 7.8 km through downtown Ottawa—equivalent to 90 Olympic-sized hockey rinks.
Ottawa was chosen as Canada's capital in 1857 by Queen Victoria as a compromise between Toronto and Montreal, and because its location on the border made it less vulnerable to American attack.
trivia: The Peace Tower on Parliament Hill contains a memorial chamber with books listing all Canadians who have died in conflicts since Confederation.
Ottawa's ByWard Market is one of Canada's oldest and largest public markets, established in 1826 by Lt-Col. John By, who also supervised the construction of the Rideau Canal.

clues: This coastal city is known for its Victorian-era architecture, tram network, and famous tennis tournament.
Famous for its laneway culture, street art, coffee scene, and often changing weather.
fun_fact: Melbourne has the largest tram system outside of Europe, with 250 km of track and 493 trams, and offers a free City Circle route for tourists.
The city has been named the world's most livable city seven times by The Economist Intelligence Unit, holding the title for seven consecutive years from 2011 to 2017.
trivia: The Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) is the largest stadium in the Southern Hemisphere, with a capacity of 100,000, and hosts cricket matches and Australian Rules Football.
The city's Royal Arcade, built in 1869, is the oldest surviving shopping arcade in Australia, featuring an iconic Gaunt's Clock with mythological figures Gog and Magog.

clues: This river city in Queensland is known for its outdoor lifestyle, subtropical climate, and annual arts festival.
Features a man-made beach in the city center and a mountain lookout offering panoramic views.
fun_fact: Brisbane's South Bank Parklands features a free, man-made beach in the middle of the city—Australia's only inner-city, man-made beach.
The Story Bridge is one of only three bridge climbs in the world (along with Sydney and Auckland) that allow climbers to scale to the top of the bridge structure.
trivia: The Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary in Brisbane is the world's first and largest koala sanctuary, established in 1927 and home to over 130 koalas.
Mount Coot-tha offers panoramic views of the city and is home to the Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium, named after the city's namesake.

clues: This isolated western city is said to be the most remote major city in the world, known for its beautiful beaches and parklands.
Famous for its Swan River, bell tower with historic bells from London, and being closer to Jakarta than to Sydney.
fun_fact: Perth is one of the most isolated major cities in the world—the nearest city with a population over 1 million is Adelaide, over 2,100 km away.
The city has more sunshine hours annually than any other Australian capital city, averaging 8.8 hours of sunshine per day or 3,200 hours per year.
trivia: Kings Park is one of the world's largest inner-city parks at 400 hectares, larger than New York's Central Park, and contains the Western Australian Botanic Garden.
The Perth Mint is Australia's oldest operating mint, established in 1899, and displays one of the largest gold coins ever created, weighing one ton and valued at over $50 million.

clues: This harbor city is built on a narrow isthmus between two harbors and on a field of dormant volcanoes.
Known as the 'City of Sails' for having more boats per capita than anywhere else in the world.
fun_fact: Auckland is built on approximately 53 dormant volcanic cones, with the most recent eruption occurring about 600 years ago.
The city has more boats per capita than anywhere else in the world, with around one in three households owning a boat, earning it the nickname 'City of Sails'.
trivia: The Sky Tower dominates Auckland's skyline at 328 meters, making it the tallest freestanding structure in the Southern Hemisphere and offering bungee jumps.
Auckland Domain, the city's oldest park, is built around the cone of an extinct volcano and houses the Auckland War Memorial Museum.

clues: This windy capital city sits at the southern tip of North Island and features a distinctive red cable car.
Known for its compact downtown area, film industry connections, and being the southernmost capital in the world.
fun_fact: Wellington is known as 'Windy Wellington' due to the strong gales that blow through the Cook Strait, with an average wind speed of 29 km/h and 173 days per year with wind gusts over 60 km/h.
The city is home to Weta Workshop, the special effects company co-founded by Peter Jackson that created the effects for 'The Lord of the Rings' films, 'Avatar', and many others.
trivia: The red Wellington Cable Car has been running since 1902, connecting downtown Lambton Quay with the Botanic Garden and offering panoramic views of the city.
The Beehive (Executive Wing of the New Zealand Parliament Buildings) is an iconic Wellington landmark designed by British architect Sir Basil Spence.

clues: This 'Garden City' was severely damaged by earthquakes in 2010-2011 and has been rebuilt with innovative architecture including a cardboard cathedral.
Known for its English heritage, flat-bottomed punting boats on the Avon River, and Antarctic exploration connections.
fun_fact: After the devastating earthquakes, Christchurch created the world's first 'Cardboard Cathedral' as a temporary replacement, designed by Japanese architect Shigeru Ban using 98 cardboard tubes.
The city is a gateway to Antarctica, with the International Antarctic Centre and the U.S., Italian, and New Zealand Antarctic programs based there.
trivia: Christchurch Botanic Gardens, founded in 1863 with an English oak tree to commemorate the marriage of Prince Albert and Princess Alexandra, now spans 21 hectares.
The Re:START Mall was a creative response to earthquake devastation, creating a shopping center out of colorful shipping containers that became a tourist attraction.
